column241: authorIndex.jsp attached - showing commented bit (that causes the scrollbar in IE)
column245:
authorIndex.jsp attached.

In the case of this file the only issue was the html style comments before the <!DOCTYPE />

Other files have other problems in addition/besides that. The most common is when the JSP produces xhtml that does not validate throwing the rendering off (Firefox is more accomodating than IE when this happens)- please take a look at the validation reports in the linked issue.

If this does not fix the issue, you can use the narrowClass definition I was talking about above. This gives more flexibility than overriding all of listHier.
column249: While on the issue of tables in SAM - would be great to set the cellpadding and cellspacing attributes of <h:dataTable styleClass="listHier" /> to "0" and let the stylesheet take care of them - the default (specifying nothing) creates white borders, noticiable in the <th />
column257:
I have attached another file that tries to explain the issue of html style comments in the prolog with IE. It is a very simple issue with a simple solution, but

This zip contains 2 modified SAM *.jsp files - put these in source of SAM where they belong, compile and deploy to see results.

authorIndex.jsp

JSP style comments are used instead of HTML comments. Because of this no HTML comment is put in response before the <!DOCTYPE /> declaration. IE does not switch to quirks mode, renders appropriately. To test mode, click on checkMode link (under "Assessments" header). IE reports CSS1Compat, as it should for that doctype.

templateIndex.jsp

Left things as they are, which means that IE will switch into quirks mode (basically not obeying the doctype declaration), which means that all rendering bets are off, and not just scrolling). To test mode, click on checkMode link (under "Templates" header). IE reports backCompat - which means that things will break, as it is not obeying the doctype.

Again, the fix is to make sure there are no HTML comments in response before <!DOCTYPE /> declaration. This will not fix everything, but it will make fixing things a lot easier, as IE will be playing by the rules we declare.

Hope this helps.

column1: [SAK-1442] Version-control and distribute Sakai architecture documentation
column6:
There are crutial Sakai design documents on collab.sakaiproject.org.

These design documents should be more widely available, as every tool developer should read them, and most Sakai production-installers should skim them at least.

I'd like to see these documents checked into SVN AND distributed with the next Sakai distribution (2.0.1).

These documents need to be version-controlled because they change over time. The Saaki 2.0.0 documents will be more fleshed out than the 2.0.1 documents, and will certainly be different from the 2.1 documents. Putting them under version control allows changes to be tracked, and the right versions can also easily be part of the Sakai download package.

They could still be available at collab.sakaiproject.org as they are now. But they'll be more useful, and more used, when they are also in SVN, directly linked-to on the release website, and downloaded as part of the distribution package.

column1: [SAK-1441] Announcement options are not saved across sessions
column6: In the "Recent Announcements" frame in the home tool, I click on options, and set the option to show the entire body of the messages. I hit save and the frame displays all of the announcements in their entirety, however if I log out and log back in, it reverts back to showing me only the first line of the announcement. I have replicated this behavior in IU's implementation of Sakai and on MIT Stable. column1: [SAK-36291] modifying question type erases question text
column6: In Tests and Quizzes, if I create a new test, add questions and then go back and decide I want to change a question type, I click "modify" and a new page displays showing the current text of the question. The page also has a dropdown list to change the question type. If I select another question type from the dropdown list, the page refreshes, and all of the question text/answer/and feedback is erased.
column10: modifying question type erases question text
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55: Ed- Do you think it would be a simple fix to save question text when you switch types? If not, reassign to me and I'm going to call it a non issue.
column90:
No such luck. Maktoto considers this a high priority bug now.

I am thinking I can create a hidden field that mirrors the first textarea (WYSIWYG) which has the question text. That field will get a new property in the backing bean. (A problem is making the WYSIWYG state such that the textarea contents are in sync without making a post, and in all browsers.)

The hidden field would start out empty.

The onchange handler will populate it as a hidden textarea mirror.

When the new page loads the hidden field will have an nonempty value.

A body onload script would examine the value and if nonempty, mirror it back.

All theoretical at this point.
I'll start experimenting tomorrow.
column95:
There are two cases where you can erase the data
1. you have entered and not saved, and,
2. you have saved.

I am going to implement a fix for #2 only, to preserve saved changes only.

That is to say, a fix for the following:
1. create a new test,
2. add questions
3. go back, deciding to change a question type, clicking "modify"
4. a new page displays showing the current text of the question.
5. select another question type
6. question text/answer/and feedback is erased.
column99:
Fix version: 1348.

Fix details:
$ svn commit -m "SAM 497: hidden fields in item type change form echo some of the data in the item form, when this form posts a change data
is persisted." jsf/author/item/itemHeadings.jsp
Sending jsf/author/item/itemHeadings.jsp
Transmitting file data .
Committed revision 1348.

Note:
The following fields, which are fairly universal for all item types, are now persisted after changing an item type on a previously saved item:

itemauthor.currentItem.itemText
itemauthor.currentItem.corrFeedback
itemauthor.currentItem.incorrFeedback
itemauthor.currentItem.generalFeedback

the answer models and other data differ so much from item to item that we didn't deem retaining them to be the correct solution, and in fact might cause other problems.
column103:
This is mostly fixed, but there's still a problem with matching questions.

If you modify a saved question and change its type to matching, the question text and feedback are lost. If you change it to any other question type, the question text and feedback get preserved.
column107:
Thanks for catching that.

Actually, the item text in the UI maps to different data for matching than for any other type in the item data model properties.

1. itemauthor.currentItem.instruction : matching
2. itemauthor.currentItem.itemText: all others

The item texts are multiple in a multiple choice and map to multiple answers. What is called the item text in the multiple choice UI is actually an instruction on how to use those texts and answers.

We can't put the multiple texts in the single text: that won't make sense.
The instruction for matching is also unlikely to make sense in a true false, upload, matching, survey etc. question text, so we can't make it copy the work in. ("Match the parts of the body with the articles of clothing, true or false?" )

I can make it retain the matching instruction and matches. That way if you accidentally change the matching type and change it back while on the same page, the data entry will not be lost (but it will be hidden until you change the question to matching). I am also going to persist the multiple choice answers and the correct answer (used for true-false).

We are probably at the point of diminishing returns here. So once I get this in, I will say "by design."
column111:
Turns out that the item data model goes through levels of conversion and validation based on item type, so that produces additional errors whne the UI model is switched from one type to another.

I was able to make the "retain but invisible" nature of the matching instructional text work, as well as retaining the item score. Because different aspects of the items types model text and answers differently persisting the answers, you will cause errors in switching item type if you do not do a significant rewrite of the backing beans, and authoring listeners. For a "Minor" level bug, this is all we will do. Therefore the other non-persisted data are by design, and not bugs per se.

So you can change a "matching" to each type in turn, and when you change it back to matching again you will see the original text.

Fix revision 1431.
Fix details:
<h:form id="itemFormHeading">
<%-- The following hidden fields echo some of the data in the item form
when this form posts a change in item type, the data is persisted.
We don't keep the answers--probably misleading for the new type.
--%>
<%-- score --%>
<h:inputHidden value="#

{itemauthor.currentItem.itemScore}

" />
<%-- non-matching type questions --%>
<h:inputHidden value="#

{itemauthor.currentItem.itemText}

" />
<%-- matching questions --%>
<h:inputHidden value="#

{itemauthor.currentItem.instruction}

" />
<%-- feedback --%>
<h:inputHidden value="#

{itemauthor.currentItem.corrFeedback}

" />
<h:inputHidden value="#

{itemauthor.currentItem.incorrFeedback}

" />
<h:inputHidden value="#

{itemauthor.currentItem.generalFeedback}

" />

NOTE: if we allow answers or matches to be retained, we would trigger null converter mismatch errors when switching types such as –
Conversion Error setting value '[org.sakaiproject.tool.assessment.ui.bean.author.AnswerBean@1d93fe7, org.sakaiproject.tool.assessment.ui.bean.author.AnswerBean@1f27c91, org.sakaiproject.tool.assessment.ui.bean.author.AnswerBean@d03fac, org.sakaiproject.tool.assessment.ui.bean.author.AnswerBean@4470f]' for 'null Converter'.

Conversion Error setting value '[org.sakaiproject.tool.assessment.ui.bean.author.MatchItemBean@182363, org.sakaiproject.tool.assessment.ui.bean.author.MatchItemBean@bb5e95, org.sakaiproject.tool.assessment.ui.bean.author.MatchItemBean@13ec519, org.sakaiproject.tool.assessment.ui.bean.author.MatchItemBean@1fdf006, org.sakaiproject.tool.assessment.ui.bean.author.MatchItemBean@992f73]' for 'null Converter'.
column115: Partial resolution.

column1: [SAK-1435] HttpSession management broken when unbinding legacy objects from session
column6:
Some objects need to be notified when they are bound or unbound from a user's HttpSession, so that they can do cleanup.

The legacy tools have an interface for this, called SessionStateBindingListener. This isn't working correctly though when the session is cleared/closed through the new Sakai 2.0 ToolSession interface.

The solution is to remove the legacy SessionStateBindingListener. There is a standard HttpSessionBindingListener which is part of the Java Servlet API, and there is also a nwe SessionBindingListener in Sakai 2.0. Switching to use these everywhere is sufficient.

Note that this does NOT cause any user-visible bugs in 2.0.0. However, in fixing things for 2.0.1, this bug did come up. Specifically, in adding a reset and help button to the JSF tools (syllabus, gradebook, Samigo, etc). So it does need to be addressed.
column10: HttpSession management broken when unbinding legacy objects from session
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55: Can we have an update on this?
column90: Fixed in HEAD, revisions r295,r296,r297. Destined for 2.0.1.
column95:
To verify that its fixed (for example, in 2.0.1), you need to edit an object, skip out of the editing in the middle by using the reset button, and then try editing again. If the bug is fixed, this will work fine. If the bug is not fixed, you won't be allowed to edit the object the 2nd time.

For example:
1. Use a legacy tool and get it into an edit state. For example, as admin, click on Worksite Setup, then select a site, then click Edit Tools.
2. Cancel the edit using the "reset" button (upper-left-hand corner of the tool's title bar, right next to the tool title).
3. Do the edit steps again. IF the bug is NOT fixed, you will be prevented from editing (it will tell you that someone is already editing the object). If the bug is fixed, you will be able to edit the site just fine.

column1: [SAK-1434] Trim error-causing spaces from *.properties files
column6:
I propose that Sakai configuration values (in sakai.properties, placeholder.properties, etc) should have extra spaces trimmed from them.

Extra spaces (such as trailing spaces) in configuration files can cause hard-to-find exceptions. Some Sakai configuration files trim extra spaces around values, others do not. Because of this, an accidental leading or trailing space can cause exceptions.

The ServerConfigurationService trims values, but the Sakai Spring extensions do not (placeholder.properties, etc). So lets make all the configuration values trimmed of extra spaces.
column10: Trim error-causing spaces from *.properties files

column1: [SAK-1433] Stale locks are not released requiring db intervention
column6:
Under some circumstances, stale locks held in the SAKAI_LOCKS table are not released, i.e. resources can remain locked by sessions which no longer exist.

This can prevent a worksite from being edited, for example.

There is no mechanism to release these locks through the Sakai web application, and the only workaround is to remove them from the underlying db.

c/f email from Glenn Golden below. There should be some mechanism for releasing stale locks automatically or periodically from within Sakai in a database-independent manner.

-------
From: "Glenn R. Golden" <ggolden@umich.edu>
To: sakai-dev <sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org>
Subject: Re: Help - locked site
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 09:37:05 -0400 (EDT)

Check your locks table. In unusual circumstances, locks can get stuck on. You can clear them manually from the database directly:

Here's some Oracle script to check the locks and clear any from closed sessions. You can use this, or just manually delete the lock record you will recognize that is out of place:

– all locks
select
TABLE_NAME, RECORD_ID, to_char(LOCK_TIME,'YYYY-MM-DD HH24:MI:SS'), USAGE_SESSION_ID, SESSION_USER, SESSION_SERVER
from SAKAI_LOCKS, SAKAI_SESSION
where USAGE_SESSION_ID = SESSION_ID
order by LOCK_TIME ASC
;

--Locks from closed sessions
select SL.TABLE_NAME, SL.RECORD_ID,
to_char(SL.LOCK_TIME,'YYYY-MM-DD HH24:MI:SS') as LOCK_TIME,
SL.USAGE_SESSION_ID,
CS.SESSION_USER,
CS.SESSION_SERVER,
to_char(CS.SESSION_END, 'YYYY-MM-DD HH24:MI:DD') as SESSION_END
from SAKAI_LOCKS SL, SAKAI_SESSION CS
where SL.USAGE_SESSION_ID = CS.SESSION_ID
and SL.USAGE_SESSION_ID NOT IN
(select session_id from chef_session where SESSION_START = SESSION_END)
order by SL.LOCK_TIME ASC;

– clear locks from closed sessions
delete from sakai_locks where usage_session_id NOT IN (select SL.USAGE_SESSION_ID from SAKAI_LOCKS SL, SAKAI_SESSION CS where SL.USAGE_SESSION_ID = CS.SESSION_ID and CS.SESSION_START = CS.SESSION_END);
column10: Stale locks are not released requiring db intervention
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55: I think this may be resolved with the implementation of optimistic locking in 2.1.x.
column90: Assumed resolved.
column95:

There is the case that happens pretty often where if a user is editing an announcement, then either navigates away or closes their browser without cancelling or saving the announcement, nobody else will be able to edit the announcement until their session is expired and the lock is removed. Perhaps this same locking or something similar needs to be made there? I can't figure out anyway to fix that lock without manually removing it from the database.

column1: [SAK-1428] No options for slide ordering - alphabetic sorting sometimes inappropriate
column6:
The presentation tool shows slides from the Resources/Presentation/... folder, ordered alphabetically.

However, when exporting a slideshow from Powerpoint (Office 2003) in PNG format, Powerpoint exports the slides as Slide1.PNG, Slide2.PNG, ..., Slide10.PNG, Slide11.PNG, etc. This set of PNG files can be easily dropped into a Resources/Presentation folder using drag&drop with WebDAV.

However, the Presentation tool shows these as Slide1.PNG, Slide10.PNG, Slide11.PNG, which is the wrong order. A correct order (in this case) would be by creation date/time, but the Presentation tool does not allow selecting alternate orderings.

The only workaround is to manually rename each SlideX.PNG file to Slide0X.PNG, which makes the end-user do more work.

column1: [SAK-1427] Configuring Sakai to use http proxy server
column6:
In environments where local network policy or firewalls require use of an upstream http proxy / cache, Sakai needs to be configured to use this.

Otherwise, components or services which use http requests, such as BasicNewsService for RSS feeds in the News tool, cannot retrieve data from the target URLs. RSS feeds then do not display in the news tool, and it is not possible to add new news channels.

This can be fixed by adding these lines to the Sakai local startup script (e.g. /etc/rc.d/sakai), or to a Sakai startup script such as startup.sh or catalina.sh:

JAVA_OPTS="-DproxySet=true -DproxyHost=cache.some.domain -DproxyPort=8080"
export JAVA_OPTS

The above information should be added to the Sakai installation documentation.

As local proxy settings are a local system configuration issue (similar to local mail relay details for example), there may also be merit in making this configurable in sakai.properties, and set at startup time or within the appropriate services using code such as:

System.getProperties().put( "proxySet", "true" );
System.getProperties().put( "proxyHost", "some_proxy" );
System.getProperties().put( "proxyPort", "8080" );
column7: Environments where local network policy requires use of http proxy
column10: Configuring Sakai to use http proxy server

column1: [SAK-1426] HELP: Search, Missing Content & Refactor

column1: [SAK-1423] worksite setup rejectes valid user ids for participants if they are email addresses
column6:
If the user id is an email address, as we encourage folks to do on Sakai Collab, worksite setup or site info will not accept these valid user ids to add as participants because it thinks they are email addresses and should be in the next box, that for "guest" accounts that get created.

Worksite setup must instead see them as valid user ids FIRST, and accept them, and only check if they are email addresses, etc, if they are not valid user ids.
column10: worksite setup rejectes valid user ids for participants if they are email addresses
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
Current behaviour:

1. With 'Worksite Setup' this works as expected. The user is able to input an email address as a authorizer's id if the authorizer uses his/her email address as an identifier.

2. With 'Site Info -> Add Participants' this does NOT work. Using an email address, although a valid user id, one gets an alert stating that the id is not a valid username.

Reopening.
column90: I think Nadine's comments are about the authorizer's id field rather than having to do with adding a user account that is an email address via the Username field of the add participants page. I could not get that to work on the 2.0.1-m1 stable builds (so the Fixed in version isn't correct I guess). I couldn't get this to work on http://nightly2.sakaiproject.org/portal but maybe I have the wrong nightly build.
column95:
The fix appears to be in nightly but not in the stable 2.0.1-m1 builds, so I am changing the fixed in version back to 2.0.1.

The fix is this (2 things) - it allows a new account creation using the add participant page when an account entered in the guest field does not already exist (it always did that), but now sends an email to the user with the password used to create the account. The email is sent by default, unless notifyNewUserEmail is set to false (in components.xml or sakai.properties).

Once the email based account exists, now it can be entered in the Username field (where before that field did not allow email addresses).
column99:
Verified on Sakai 2.0.1-rc1

Unassigning & closing item.

column1: [SAK-1421] Importing question from qpool problems
column6:
verified on all 3 nightly 2.0 builds at Stanford.

New and strange. When you're authoring an assessment and try to import a question from a question pool, over half the time Samigo goes to the question pools screen instead of the import screen. It seems to happen most often in new assessments that don't already have questions.

Steps to reproduce:

1) Create a new assessment.
2) In the questions screen, choose "Copy question from question pool".
3) Click on the name of the pool you want to import from.
4) Double-check the page. Does the button at the bottom say "Import" (right) or "Update" (wrong)?

Since the two screens look similar, it's very easy to not notice and select questions to import, only to find out when you hit the button that what you were doing was deleting them.

column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

However, when I did it, I got the right screen.

I tried three times and I couldn't get it to go wrong.

Of course I don't have as many test scenerios as you do.

Lydia said to assign it to her if you can show her how to reproduce it.

column1: [SAK-1420] Model short answer link in grading doesn't go anywhere
column6:
Sakai - 2.0.0 - Sakai 2.0.0[506121] (all 3 nightly qa builds)

When you view the submitted answers to a SA question in grading, there's a "Model Short Answer" link below the text box with the student's answer. Currently that link doesn't do anything.

The link should bring up a popup window with the model short answer for the question (if there is one).
column10: Model short answer link in grading doesn't go anywhere
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55: Margaret - Can you verify if this is only FF or other browsers?
column90:
Yes, it happens in both IE and gecko-based browsers. (Sorry, I should have put that in the original report.)

I tested it again using alternately short (one-line) and longer model short answers for questions.

In grading, the entire model SA is automatically displayed as part of the question view, no matter how long or short it is.

The "click here" link either does nothing (for short model answers) or brings up the desired popup (for long model answers). There's two problems with this behavior:

  • it's confusing to have a link that doesn't go anywhere, suggesting that there's more model answer you can't get to.
  • If the whole model short answer is always displayed right on the page, you don't need a link to a popup at all.
column95:
I removed the model short answer in the gradestudentanswer page, now it is only seen by clicking the link.

But the link works for me at this point, either for the short model answers or the long model answers. Magaret, could you double check this again? Thanks.

column1: [SAK-1419] Adding random draw part in authoring removes questions in other parts
column6:
Sakai - 2.0.0 - Sakai 2.0.0[506121] (nightly stanford qa instances), all 3 db types

New and weird. If you add questions to the first part of a new assessment and then create a second random draw part, the questions in the first part will vanish. (If you then put them back, they'll stay.)

Doesn't happen if you add a regular part instead, or if you put the random draw part first.

Steps to reproduce:

1) Create a new assessment.

2) Add one or more questions to the default part.

3) Add a new random draw part.

4) The random draw part will be created, but the default part will suddenly have 0 questions in it.

column207:
Aha! Ed says:

Pools are composed of "floating" questions, they are partless. When those questions are put into assessments, they represent real logical links back to the pools. They are not copies, and reflect any edits or updates in real time.

Apparently, when you create a random draw part from a question pool, the section id (part) gets associated with that section, only. As soon as that is done, no other part anywhere in any assessment can use that question pool. You can't assign multiple parts to a question. This was by design.

—

So I should discuss this with Marc and document it in the release notes.
column211:
According to Lydia, this is by design. Questions exist without parts within a pool.
They are assigned a part when they are part of a random draw. They should not be reassigned.

Accordingly: documentation issue.
column215:
This has been address in 2.1.
Please see fix for SAK-2779 Closed for details.

column1: [SAK-1418] Notification when Chat/Discussion is ongoing

Notify site members when a new discussion post or chat room is created.

A user requested a notification when someone posts a discussion message or enters a chat room. This would improve the capability of the two tools to act in real-time. One possibility would be an email notification, which would probably be fine for discussion, but not so good for chat. Maybe some modified version of the presence tool could work, if it indicated users in chat instead of users in the overall site.

column195:
Special instructions for folks upgrading from 2.0.0 to 2.0.1 who have customized their portal.css and/or tool.css

  • - - - - - - - - - - - - -

The accessibility work detailed above included some changes to the portal.css and tool.css. To review:

1 - <h1> were added to the portal before the following blocks: a) the site tabs, b) the tools, c) the content.

2 - The tool titles inside the tool title iframe are now bracketed by <h2>

Both these changes were needed to make the portal easier to navigate with a screen reader. The default rendering of th e<h> headers, whowever, would interfere with the sighted readers experience, so this issue was dealt with in the css, namely by:

  • adding a class to the portal.css to render the <h1> off screen (the <h1> are classed "skip"):

.skip {
position:absolute; top:-999px;
left:-999px; height:0;width:0
}

The use of this selector in the portal also "hides" all the "jumpto" and "skipto" links and targets that have been added.

  • addressing the <h2> in the tool titles contextually in the tool.css

.toolTitle td.title h2{
font: normal bold 12px Arial, sans-serif;
margin:0;
padding:0;
display:inline
}

Your own needs may dictate a different font, etc - the important thing is to override the default rendering of h2, and the padding and margin and "inline" definition are inmportant in this regard.

column1: [SAK-1414] Reduce Gradebook-specific JSF via Sakai-wide JSF
column6:
(This is actually a shared task for the Gradebook and JSF components.)

For 2.1, some added JSF functionality created to deliver the Gradebook should be reviewed, revised as necessary, and replaced by Sakai-wide JSF functionality. In at least two cases this might add extensions that can be used by other Sakai applications: a JSF Messages renderer that displays messages in <div> tags rather than <span> tags, and the new FlowState tag that supports request thread scope. In other cases, we just need to ensure that existing Sakai-wide extensions meet the application's needs (e.g., the locally defined sortable column header).

Although it's not a large task, I've marked the priority "Major" since it's a dependency for a proposed new 2.1 tool and we don't want to let Gradebook stray too far into a local dialect.
column10: Reduce Gradebook-specific JSF via Sakai-wide JSF
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55: This relates to eliminating the Gradebook-specific date-selection widget.
column90: Will this task be completed for 2.1.0?
column95: Some parts have already been done, some parts will slop over. It may be best for me to close this one out after creating finer-grained tasks for the work left to be done.
column99:
The formerly Gradebook-only FlowState and PhaseAware components have been relocated to Sakai JSF. Here are the remaining iffy cases and what I think we should do about them.

  • HtmlSortHeaderRenderer : TWO COPIES, ONE IN GRADEBOOK, ONE IN SECTIONS. This builds on the MyFaces sorting table header renderer in two ways: 1) Supports a CSS class to distinguish the currently selected column. 2) Allows a nice icon to be used to indicate directionality. It looks as if the new version of the MyFaces component gives the image support, but still not the CSS class support. We should move this functionality into Sakai JSF or submit it to MyFaces, but it can wait until after 2.1.
  • DivMessageRenderer, DivMessagesRenderer : TWO COPIES, ONE IN GRADEBOOK, ONE IN SECTIONS. This provides valuable otherwise unavailable formatting support, but currently stores messages in a session-scoped bean. That makes it too eccentric to move into the Sakai JSF library. To get rid of the redundancy and make it easier for other applications to use, we should make the changes necessary to productize this (and perhaps offer it to the MyFaces Tomahawk effort). Definitely a post-2.1 task!
  • calendar.js - We broke the calendar popup JavaScript out into our own application code because of a bug in the MyFaces calendar component. The need for that should be re-examined once we upgrade to the the latest version of the MyFaces components. This upgrade will happen post-2.1.
  • Iterator, DhtmlPopup - This are new components, currently only in the Gradebook. After their trial-by-fire in QA, I think they'll both be worth "productizing". Post-2.1, I'll talk to Ed about whether to do that in Sakai or by submitting them to MyFaces.
column103: Ray, you probably want to capture your last set of comments as new issues in Jira, as this Task is now complete, so it should be resolved and closed so folks know what is going into 2.1.0. The post-2.1 work should go elsewhere. Thanks.
column107: Agreed, Peter. I've already started talking to the relevant parties about the next steps, and I'll open new feature requests or tasks as the decisions get made.

column1: [SAK-1402] Same course taught in successive years has same tab name
column6:
When instructors of record add a site for a course that they have taught before, the new site has the same name as the previous semester's site. With the tabbed interface, a professor who teaches the same course regularly over a number of semesters- such as intro language classes which may be offered 3 or 4 semesters a year- the instructor could end up with half a dozen sites with the same name. We have several suggestions for the problem:

1. Allow professors to control site names [last resort]
2. Rework Tab management screen so that additional information, such as the term a class was taught, is visible in the selection interface so that instructors can easily differentiate between courses when sorting and arranging them. [good solution]
3. Tack on additional characters to system-defined names to designate the term a course was taught. [most preferred solution, if it's possible]
column10: Same course taught in successive years has same tab name
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
It would be easy for us to add a term designator to the site's name when the site is created - W04, F05, SpSu05 etc. I think that should be done and have wanted to do it for UM at least for some time. It will have to be done in a way that is 'generic'. Since creating a class site in generic Sakai requires picking a term then I think we will always have a term designator that we can add to the class name (we have in sakai.properties

  1. term titles
    termlistabbr.count=7
    termlistabbr.1 = F03
    termlistabbr.2 = W04
    termlistabbr.3 = Sp04
    termlistabbr.4 = SpSu04
    termlistabbr.5 = Su04
    termlistabbr.6 = F04
    termlistabbr.7 = W05
    so institutions can decide what they want the designators to be.
column90: This is becoming a problem for every SEPP I've talked to starting up. We should go ahead and fix since it is an easy fix. Note that we should handle the case where there are no term abbreviations defined (don't add a term to the title).

column1: [SAK-1401] SVN server does not provide renderable HTML
column6:
If you click on

https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn/trunk/sakai/gradebook/xdocs/specs/GB2reqSpec.html

the html is not rendered.
column10: SVN server does not provide renderable HTML
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
The problem:

The SVN server sends a mime-type when it serves up a file. The default mime-type is "text/plain". When a browser receives that mime-type, it interprets the file as plain text, so the HTML isn't rendered.

The solution:
There are two parts - for newly added files, and for existing files.

I changed the SVN client-side configuration to set the mime-type of *.html and *.htm to text/html (automatically). Developers should get the new config file, and then when they checkin new *.html files it'll be fine.

Existing *.html files need their mime-types reset to "text/html". I can't do that for the gradebook since I don't have checkin permissions. But I can do it for the other files, which I'll do now.
column90: That link now worked fine for me when I tried it this morning (with Safari).
column95:
This "bug" only appears on browsers that properly use the mime-type header. Mozilla-based browsers (Firefox, Netscape) take the mime-type as authorative - so when they see the (incorrect) mime-type "text/plain", they show the file as plain text even though its actually HTML. Other browsers (Safari, IE) use heuristics to guess that even though the file says "text/plain" it actually looks like HTML.

To recap, the "bug" only appears on standards-complient browsers.
column99: It sounds like someone with permissions on Gradebook needs to update those files, and then this issue can be closed.
column103: Mind taking this on?
column107: No problem... done.

column1: [SAK-1399] Replace date-picker with better standard component
column6:
Largely because of schedule conflicts, the 2.0 Gradebook uses a simple popular JavaScript calendar for its date-picking. Since this is a standard piece of functionality, the application should use a standard widget.

Also, advances have been made in DHTML since the script was written. It should now be possible for the popup-pseudo-window to be draggable, which would boost usability when screen real estate is tight.
column10: Replace date-picker with better standard component
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
In some ways the Gradebook date picker is better than the one used elsewhere. It's cleaner (visually and in moving from month to month), and I like the drop-down lists for selecting month & year.

On the other hand I agree that "dragability" is useful for repositioning.
column90:
For Sakai 2.2, we upgraded to MyFaces 1.1, and their "calendar" JSF component now works. In revision 8310, the Gradebook therefore dropped its direct use of the JavaScript code.

Since the MyFaces component relies on the same basic JavaScript, however, more advanced features such as draggability still aren't there, and so I'll keep this open until moving the feature request to the JSF component.

This is a NEW exception.

However, it appears that the selected type string is getting in as not null, but blank, based on the new error you have given me. Only null is tested. The code will attempt to convert a blank string to a number. I am just making it default to multiple choice in that case. It appears that the only way to get to that condition is to whang away a lot on the poor little dropdown--in the field, a user must have made a last minute change. If so, they may have no real expectations as to what they selected, so I think this is fine. Unlike a dangling chad or overvote we may not know what they wanted, but unlike the 2000 election, we can offer them a second chance.

There may be other error conditions that exist, but this should prevent the error cited above from ever occuring.

column1: [SAK-35442] Submission ID links missing on total scores page
column6:
all 3 stable MIT 2.0 rc3 builds

Nadine found this one.

If you release an assessment to anonymous users only, and you also change the grading settings to "student names visible", then the submission ID links on the total scores page will be missing. So there's no way to view Student Scores for those assessments.

Steps to reproduce:

1) Create an assessment with an all-settings-open template.

2) Add a question to it.

3) In Assessment Settings, change "release to" to be anonymous only.

4) In Assessment Settings, change the first grading option to "Student's identities can be seen by graders".

5) Publish the assessment and note the published assessment URL.

6) Log out of Sakai, then visit the published assessment url and take the assessment.

7) Submit for grading.

8) Log back into Sakai and view the assessment scores.

9) On the Total Scores page, you'll see the submission, but the field where the ID link should be is empty.
column10: Submission ID links missing on total scores page
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
Fixed. The right scenario here should be a link with name "Anonymous" which points to the student scores page.
Please double check.

Thanks,
Qingru

column1: [SAK-1382] License review - ctools
column6: See parent task SAK-1372 Closed for the task description.
column10: License review - ctools
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
From Dick Ellis 6/27/05

Dave,

Here's a quick summary for ctools. It's standard legacy stuff.

1. svn/trunk/ctools isn't distributed with sakai. It seems unlikely, therefore, that anyone would find a license problem therein.
2. All java files carry a statement on behalf of the core institutions "Copyright 2003, 2004 ECL" except ReservesAction.java, which has "Copyright 2003, 2004, 2005 ECL".
3. VM_chef_library has macros, i.e., units of code, but no license statement. I did wonder in this case.
4. All .vm files have VTL code, of course, and no license statement; some have minor javascript. NBD.
5. .classpath, .project, project.xml, velocity.properties, web.xml have no license statement. I did wonder with web.xml, because of the connection with the Sun JCP Servlet spec. Configuration files seem like a hybrid of work of art/code - content is programatic but in English.
6. The GIF question I sent you
7. DissertationUploadAction.java uses org.sakaiproject.util.FileItem for upload. If there is an issue with FileItem it would apply here, too.

That's about it. If there is any work to be done for any of these items, I can identify the specific files involved.

Dick

Dick Ellis
Digital Media Commons
University of Michigan
(734) 615-2549
column90: We should only have to worry about licenses in the java and javascript code. The .classpath, .project. *.xml, *.vm files we don't need insert a specific license for, unless there is embedded javascript that is non-trivial.
column95: the files reviewed
column99: It is clean.

column1: [SAK-1381] Disable back and cancel buttons when creating a site
column6: At the last stage of creating a site, you get the Request Site/Create Site button. When you click it, it becomes grayed out, and the system throws up a little message that it is working. However, you can still click on Back or Cancel. When I clicked Back, it took me back to the previous stage. However, when I tried to progress go forward again, the frame went blank and I had to go back to the beginning of Worksite Setup. It turned out that the site had been created, though.
column10: Disable back and cancel buttons when creating a site
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
I'm still seeing the same behavior in rc2. After I press "Request Site" during site creation, if I keep hitting "Back" and "Cancel," it eventually takes me back to the previous step, but instead of being able to go forward, the frame just goes blank when I proceed to the next step.

If you'd like to recreate this to observe it:
1. Go through site creation process until you get to the page where you click on "Request Site" (or "Create Site" if creating a project site)
2. Click on Request Site
3. Click on the Cancel and Back buttons a lot. Really, keep clicking them, like you just realized you made a horrible mistake and want desperately for one of them to work.

column1: [SAK-1379] SAMigo customized tool provisioning based on use case
column6:
We would like to see the SAMigo UI customized at runtime by passing a flag of sorts. The use case is as follows:

1) If the tool placement of SAMigo is in a survey only mode, then the question types available in authoring would be specific to survey use.

2) If the tool placement of SAMigo is in assessment mode, then only assessment question types would be displayed during authoring.

In fact, we would like to be able to have separate instances of the SAMigo tool available. For example, in worksite setup one would see a tool called "Surveys" and another tool called "Assessments". SAMigo could then customize its behavior as described above (#1 and #2) based on whether it is the Survey tool or Assessment tool.

We are finding that the term "Tests & Quizzzes" does not have the right semantic meaning in a project site. In addition, the term "Tests & Quizzes" is not ideal when used in a formative assessment methodology.

Thanks, L
column10: SAMigo customized tool provisioning based on use case
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

column1: [SAK-1378] T&Q:  Checking MO:  Cannot view scores for Inactive Assessments
column6:
Once the due date for an assessment has passed, the assessment goes into the inactive section of the "Published Assessments" area of the page. The problem is that if I want to review who has taken the assessment, or even to review the scores, I am unable to do so as the 'Scores' link is not available.

As an instructor, there are instances when it is necessary to go back and take a look at previously submitted tests and quizzes, even if the date for allowing the student to take the assessment has passed.

ISSUE:
Don't you think the instructor should always be allowed to review scores? As an instructor, one can get challenges to grades even into the following semester.

Is this a bug or a feature request?
column10: T&Q:  Checking MO:  Cannot view scores for Inactive Assessments
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55: I would certainly expect to be able to view past ones.
column90: Yup. This is a bug that was fixed earlier but has appeared again. Closing as duplicate of SAK-35264 Closed .

column107:
Margaret,

HSQLDB lives in memory so I won't be able to check your instance now.

Question: when creating the site, did you select Gradebook as one of the tool for the site. If not, the Gradebook option is not going to show up in assessment. However, the Gradebook option will show up in template. If you create a site with the Gradebook selected, you should see the Gradebook option. Can you confirm? Thanks.

Daisy
column111:
Aha! Not only does the Gradebook tool have to be enabled on the site, but at least one assignment must be in the gradebook already. Until that happens the gradebook setting won't be visible or set in core assessments.

Steps to reproduce:
1) log into a mysql or hsql instance.
2) Create a new worksite. Add both the T&Q and Gradebook tools.
3) Create a new assessment in T&Q, using an open template (all settings viewable/editable).
4) Check the assesssment settings. No gradebook option under Grading.
5) Go to the Gradebook tool. Create a new assignment there.
6) Return to T&Q and check the settings of that same assessment. Now the gradebook setting is there.

column10: license review - add missing license to Sakai-developer written files

column55:
I've added the Sakai license to the source that was written by Sakai developers (except for Samigo).

Samigo has a bunch of source files without any license listed in the source. It looks like this is just an oversight, as the code was written by Sakai developers.

It appears to me that there are a few files with multiple licenses (Apache + Sakai), and a few with only a non-Sakai license. However, the only project that has Java source files without any license, at this point, is Samigo. Once that is cleaned up, there will be a license on every source file.

column1: [SAK-1373] License review - gradebook
column6: jira to track license review for gradebook. See parent Jira entry.
column10: License review - gradebook
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
The only non-original file in the Gradebook source tree is the JavaScript-based date picker at:

sakai/gradebook/tool/src/webapp_common/calendar

This is closely based on code from Apache MyFaces 1.09, which in turn was closely based on a widely distributed public domain chunk of JavaScript.

I've just added more documentation to the central file, "popcalendar.js". I'll append that to this comment as well.

As noted below, the "calendar" subdirectory is a temporary stopgap for us, and should be eliminated by 2.1. (Possibly even by 2.01, but the priority of the task isn't currently high enough to ensure that.)

Please let me know if you need any more information about any of this.

===

/*

  • This code is based closely on the version of Tan Ling Wee's popular
  • script distributed with Apache MyFaces 1.0.9 as:
    *
  • src/components/org/apache/myfaces/custom/calendar/resource/popcalendar.js
    *
  • No licensing information is embedded in the MyFaces version of the file,
  • but the MyFaces product is developed and distributed under the terms of
  • The Apache Software License, Version 2.0.
    *
  • Some changes have been made to work around problems relating
  • to MyFaces's way of loading component resource dependencies.
  • Changes are flagged with the comment "// *** GRADEBOOK ***".
    *
  • TO DO: Replace with a standard UI date-picking component when one is
  • available.
    */
column90: The JIRA task for eliminating the "calendar" subdirectory is SAK-1399 Closed .
column95: Just spotted a file I missed in the earlier sweep. I'll take another look round while I'm at it.
column99:
This file slipped through on my first pass since it has so little in common with its original source:

gradebook/tool/src/java/org/sakaiproject/tool/gradebook/jsf/HtmlSortHeaderRenderer.java

Based very slightly on the MyFaces class of the same name, with the standard Apache license. We've modified it extensively. I've added comments on the changes and copied the original's header into the source to be on the safe side.

(As with the date picker, this functionality should ideally be moved out of application-specific code for 2.1.)

column1: [SAK-1372] license review
column6:
Code distributed with Sakai needs to be viewed for license status. Below is a copy of an email describing the tasks.

I spoke with Barnaby Gibson of the Ithaka organization about licensing issues. There is some work we need to do.

To make sure we don't have license rot developers should not just download and add code that looks good to them. Developers need to take responsibility to find the license, read it, and ask questions about anything that isn't clear about it. Sakai needs to have a copy of the license and be able to be in compliance with the license. Checking the license should not be onerous. We'll have a list of ones that have been reviewed and decisions about those will be easy. A number of licenses are clearly ok: Apache, BSD. Some are clearly not OK: GPL and other viral licenses. Use of LGPL licensed code requires care. Others can be brought up and we can figure out how they fit in. There will be some things we just can't use.

We should have a clear license for each file. For most Sakai developed files we are OK. However there are some files:

  • that don't have a license and it isn't clear where they came from.
  • created by Sakai developers that don't contain a license.
  • where we don't comply with the license.
  • where it is unclear if we comply with the license.

We need to make the licensing state of the code as easy to determine.

To get the licensing as clear as possible we should take the following actions.

  • maintain a list of which external code is used, where it is used, the context of use, and the license that applies.
  • maintain a copy of all the licenses.
  • create an 'about' or 'credits' page in the Sakai gateway that contains the credits that some licenses require.
  • review code to put in licenses where needed, extract copies of licenses when needed, make sure that license conditions are acceptable and are met.
  • replace code where we won't comply with the license.
  • make sure all code clearly contains its license.

I'll take on current responsibility for dealing with the jar dependencies, maintaining the lists, trying to get questions answered, and building the credits page, but licensing compliance is not a one person job. Joseph and Chuck have agreed to a plan that distributes review of the code to the originating institution. The tasks of the review would be:

  • make sure that Sakai code files include a copy of the ECL. This includes changing the license used in the Samigo code to be the ECL.
  • identify code that wasn't written for Sakai, find the license, read it, make sure there is a copy in the Confluence license area, and make sure that the Sakai use of it is in compliance. If the use of the file is not clearly in compliance with the license let me know. It also needs to be clear to someone who downloads Sakai what license applies to these files. This may require adding licenses to some external files, or including a license.txt file or some other method. We can determine the exact method to use on a case by case basis.

When external code is found we need to update the Confluence licensing page. I'll do that if I'm sent a copy of the following information about the non-sakai code (if the information is not already on the Confluence licensing site): file/jar name, purpose, license name, modification status, when is it used (compile time / run time), and notes . The notes should include the context it which it is used if appropriate. I'll need the information required for a credit also.

Questions that come up can be referred to me and I'll try to get them answered.

From Kevin Chan (kevin at media.berkeley.edu):

After further testing, I have found the "bad" parts of sakai.properties (from the sakai-src package) that is causing the problem:

--begin section

  1. appearance setup for worksite setup
  2. each appearance option has a name (iconNames.X), a url to the icon (iconUrls.X), and a possible skin (iconSkins.X)
  3. if no skin is defined, the default is used
    iconNames.count=2
    iconNames.1=Sakai
    iconNames.2=Example

iconUrls.count=2
iconUrls.1=
iconUrls.2=

iconSkins.count=2
iconSkins.1=
iconSkins.2=examp-u
--end section

column1: [SAK-1369] Anonymously published, submitted assessments not showing up in "Submitted Assessments" section for student
column6:
Something I forgot to post previously.

1. Logged in as flmover1 ('registered' user – ie, student)
2. Accessed the 'T&Q' tool from "NB - Project 1" worksite

Listed there are 4 assessments that I'm assuming were anonymously published, as they were not created from this worksite.

3. Accessed one of the assessments.
4. Took the assessment and submitted for grading

ISSUE:
The assessment does not show up in the "Submitted Assessments" area as one that has been submitted by the student. It goes off into never-never-land.

Is this how anonymously published assessments are to behave?
column10: Anonymously published, submitted assessments not showing up in "Submitted Assessments" section for student
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
That's a good question. I remember another bug about whether or not assessments should show up in the "submitted assessments" list if they belong to other sites, and the answer was no.

In other words, if you're in the T&Q section of site Foo, you'll see all the assessments available for you to take, no matter what site they were published in. But the "Submitted Asessments list" will only show you the Foo-related assessments that you took.

This seems inconsistent. If you don't know what site an assessment belongs to, then you don't know where to go to review it.
column90: An anonymous assessment, by definition, should not be connected with a particular user. Therefore, a user should not see an anonymously submitted assessment in their Submitted Assessments list. Same goes for Available Assessments, but that's another story.
column95: In SAK-1352 Closed , I'm recommending that anonymous not be listed at all. Access should be URL only.

Just some thoughts.

Josh

column1: [SAK-1363] Allow portal CSS skinning based on site types (course, project, workspace, etc).
column6:
We need the skins to be able to have slightly different appearances for different site types. A single skin needs to do slightly different styling for workspace sites vs. course sites vs. project sites vs. other sitetype-sites. To accomplish this, the site type will be included in the style output from the portal, for two important elements.

Currently the navigation has the following two elements:

<div class="tabHolder">....

<div id="container">....

We need to change them to the following:

<div class="tabHolder workspace">...
<div class="tabHolder course">...
<div class="tabHolder project">...

<div id="container" class="workspace">...
<div id="container" class="course">...
<div id="container" class="project">...

Then a single portal skin can (for example), have slightly different colors for each site type.
column10: Allow portal CSS skinning based on site types (course, project, workspace, etc).
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
Portal is now outputting site type instructions into the markup (thanks Jon!)- these are used now by the css to render different types of sites in different ways with the same skin.

This is true only for CTools - other institutions could make use of it if they wanted to. A caveat - the Ctools css assumes that the site types are "workspace, course, project" - other institutions may be using different stite types

column1: [SAK-1361] No Permissions toolbar action in Gradebook
column6: There's no way for a site owner to set the permissions in Gradebook. Old sites that add Gradebook won't be able to specify who can maintain and who has an entry in the gradebook.
column10: No Permissions toolbar action in Gradebook
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
The 2.0 Gradebook asks only whether a user is in the role of maintain (instructor) or access (student). There are no tool-specific decisions to be made around AuthZ. This is the way GB has been speced since we scaled it back early in the year. I believe it parallels Samigo in this regard, although the implementation is different.

John, can you explain in more detail what the problem is and what you mean by "old sites"? Are these CTools sites that carry over from term to term with previously defined roles comprising permissions more finely grained than maintain and access?
column90:
Whether a site participant shows up in the gradebook or not is controlled by the gradebook.access permission in their role. Whether they can edit the gradebook is controlled by the gradebook.maintain permission in their role. In Sakai OOTB, the roles of access and maintain have the appropriate permission checked. At any particular institution, installers would configure the system with whatever roles they want, and give those roles the appropriate gradebook permissions. That would affect sites created from then on.

It could be that an installation might want to run some script to update old site roles with the new gradebook permissions (since the new permissions wouldn't be checked in the old site realms - those permissions weren't there when the old site realms were created at the time the site was created).

But failing that, site owners would want to, if they added gradebook, set the permissions accordingly. This would be for those sites that happen to be in use that want to add gradebook.

In general though, a Sakai tool with permission settings has a Permissions page so that permissions can be changed per role. Site owners should be able to fuss with the permissions - they may want to change the ability of an assistant to edit the gradebook for example, without having to get support involved.
column95: Have a workaround until fixed.
column99:
Producing a separate application-specific "permissions" UI was never part of our requirements. If I follow your description, this isn't a bug but a new feature request that has to prioritized and specified.

I should admit, though, that we don't understand the justification for the proposed feature. The Gradebook isn't meant to be a completely standalone application. It's meant to be plugged into a framework that controls authentication, roles, and group membership, and that framework should have an adminstrative application that lets users manage these things. Since the Gradebook application itself knows nothing about how permissions and roles are implemented by the framework, it's in no position to tamper with them.

In the case of Sakai 2.0, the framework integration code feeds the Gradebook permission and role information via the two system permissions "gradebook.access" and "gradebook.maintain". We didn't define those permissions, we just passively translate them into internal roles. In my test deployments, they show up in the legacy Realms administrative tool along with everything else.

Is there some other piece that we're missing? If so, please re-open this issue or submit a new bug report with the details.
column103:
The point is that there are two permissions which control access to the Gradebook in a site - gradebook.access and gradebook.maintain. For the roles in a site, the instructor may want to change who can do what to the gradebook. They can't without a call to support, since the only way to set them is via the Admin Realm editor. A Sakai tool that has permission settings need to have a Permissions page so that the site owner can change permissions for that tool. Aside from being consistent with other Sakai tools.

It doesn't have to do with Gradebook being standalone or not, but with the ability for a site owner to determine which roles get to do what in their site.
column107: Again, this sounds like a feature request to me, and again, it sounds like something which needs to be prioritized against other tasks (e.g., a section and roles application which lets instructors avoid the legacy admin tools). I'm forwarding it to the project manager to decide whether to change the type from "Bug" or not.
column111:
For the benefit of those more familiar with the legacy tools approach, some further background might be helpful.

As I wrote above, the Gradebook is explicitly a passive receiver of permission information, and was never intended to change membership rosters or roles.

Partly that's a simple matter of separation of concerns: grading and creating assignments is a very different task from administering groups and roles. It has different UI needs, different work flow profiles, a different relationship to institutional data and rules, and so forth.

In this particular case, it's also partly because the permissions of greatest interest (permission to change assignment definitions and permissions to grade students) are not specific to the application. Samigo (and any other application that feeds a gradebook) needs to share the same underlying permission settings if over LMS/CLE integrity is to be maintained. That means that the framework both our applications share should be feeding us the same permission data.

Especially once permissions scoped by sections come into play, the administrative functions become far too complex for instructors to handle unless they're bundled into roles and managed by an application specifically designed for that task.
column115:
This feature will not make it into the 2.1 release.

It should be noted again that all of the non-legacy Sakai tools lack the permissions link. Please see above comments for why it is not part of the gradebook.
column139:
The other non-legacy tools did have permissions pages at one time, but they were removed because the tools didn't actually have any permission settings enabled.

See above for explanation of why Gradebook should have a permission page.

Perhaps we can find a developer to get it in as we will likely be working on getting the Assignment tool hooked up to Gradebook.
column187: As I understand it, this is a Michigan specific problem with old sites. This issue should not affect new deployments of Sakai. There are very compelling reasons for keeping the permissions link out of tools that will become section aware and which will share permissions for interoperability reasons. If Michigan independently chooses to alter the gradebook outside of the 2.1 GB subproject effort, then that code will live outside of the SVN trunk.
column191:
Just to kibbutz, there might be some other approaches, too.

  • Get someone to do a quick utility sweep (legacy API based, DB based, screen scraping based, whatever) adding "gradebook.maintain" across appropriate users.
  • Add a limited permissions-management tool for instructors.
  • Have a local branch where the implementation of the Authz facade:

gradebook/tool/src/java/org/sakaiproject/tool/gradebook/facades/sakai2impl/AuthzSakai2Impl.java

uses a different criterion. If you do hook up the Assignment tool, you'll have to make sure that its grading permission matches the Gradebook's, and so that seems like a natural choice.
column195:
In discussion with Chuck Severance last week, it became clear that we probably went wrong during the Sakai 2.0 integration fest when Josh was steered towards creating and checking two new Gradebook-branded permissions. Instead, we should have stuck with our original plan, which was to just check for site "access" or "maintain" until the new common services were in place.

In the meeting, we agreed that it might be worth changing the facade implementation in the current source tree:

gradebook/tool/src/java/org/sakaiproject/tool/gradebook/facades/sakai2impl/AuthzSakai2Impl.java

We could then offer a patch to institutions who were having problems with old sites. On reflection, though, the change doesn't seem so attractive: it's not backwardly compatible with 2.0 and Gradebook authorization logic will completely change for 2.1 anyway.

Since it's a two-liner, the local branch idea doesn't seem that terrible as a workaround for now.

column6: When the attached file is uploaded to Resources, and then opened by clicking on its title in Resoures, some of the characters are not showing up properly.
column10: Problems uploading/editing Resources with non-standard characters

column55:
Sorry - the problem is not when clicking on its title, but when clicking edit underneath its title.

To clarify (my description wasn't) -
If I click on it to edit, I get the bad chars showing, so it is indeed with the wysiwyg widget I think. If I click on the item title to open it , things show up fine. If I download it, and open from local disk, it shows up fine. So I retract my blocker status. Seems just a problem with how the wysiwyg is showing it (and so wasn't a problem in 1.5, since we didn't allow inline editing of uploaded text files there I think, or if we did, it wasn't using the wysiwyg..
column90: Workaround in the meantime: download file and open it, rather than opening it in WYSIWIG.
column95:
This looks like an encoding issue.

When a file is uploaded, Sakai honors the character encoding the file comes with. The WYSIWYG, however, always expects UTF-8, and stores back in UTF-8. So there may be a mismatch there. We may be able to fix it by being more careful about character encoding when sending/restoring from the WYSIWYG.
column99:
I think there are at least two issues here. The original bug report referred to plain text files that were uploaded and then opened for editing. Text files get edited in a simple textarea, rather than the WYSIWYG editor. We are using validator escape routines when we put text into the textarea. I think that's corrupting them in some way. For example, I created a file containing the following line (copied and pasted from this ticket):

Àlição.txt (0.1 kb)

When I saved it and edited it, it came back as follows:

¿Äli¿ß¿£o.txt (0.1 kb)

When I saved that and edited it again, it came back as:

¿àö¿Ñli¿àö¿ü¿àö¬£o.txt (0.1 kb)

When I saved that and edited it again, it came back as:

¿Äö¿¿¿¿¿àö¿ëli¿Äö¿¿¿¿¿àö¿º¿Äö¿¿¿¿¬¨¬£o.txt (0.1 kb)

When I saved that and edited it again, it came back as:

¿Äö¿Ñ¿¿¿àö¿Ä¿¿àö¿àÇ¿Äö¿¿¿¿¿àö¿´li¿Äö¿Ñ¿¿¿àö¿Ä¿¿àö¿àÇ¿Äö¿¿¿¿¿àö¬¿¿Äö¿Ñ¿¿¿àö¿Ä¿¿àö¿àÇ¬¨¬®¬¨¬£o.txt (0.1 kb)

When I saved that and edited it again, it came back as:

¿Äö¿Ñ¿¿¿àö¿ë¿àö¿àÇ¿Äö¿¿¿¿¿Äö¿Ñ¿Ä¿¿Äö¿¿¿¿¿Äö¿¿¿á¿Äö¿Ñ¿¿¿àö¿Ä¿¿àö¿àÇ¿Äö¿¿¿¿¿àö¬¥li¿Äö¿Ñ¿¿¿àö¿ë¿àö¿àÇ¿Äö¿¿¿¿¿Äö¿Ñ¿Ä¿¿Äö¿¿¿¿¿Äö¿¿¿á¿Äö¿Ñ¿¿¿àö¿Ä¿¿àö¿àÇ¿Äö¿¿¿¿¬¨¿à´¿Äö¿Ñ¿¿¿àö¿ë¿àö¿àÇ¿Äö¿¿¿¿¿Äö¿Ñ¿Ä¿¿Äö¿¿¿¿¿Äö¿¿¿á¬¨¬®¬¨¬Æ¬¨¬®¬¨¬£o.txt (0.1 kb)

You get the idea. Escape routines should be reversible, and we should always reverse the escape process to maintain the integrity of the data. Not sure if this is happening in our code or in the tomcat code. I will try to answer that question.

The other issue is that a similar thing happens in the WYSIWYG editor when we edit html files. Not sure if that is in the editor, our escape reoutines or the tomcat code.

column229:
The confusion may come from the original file. I'm uploading a second copy, with a slight difference.

Alicao-2.txt has been resaved as UTF-8. The original was ISO-Latin-1. Since Sakai is serving pages as UTF-8 and does no conversion on uploaded files, munged output is a reasonable, predictable, and expected result - in fact, the output is not munged - if you manually switch the encoding of your web browser to Latin1 you'll see the correct characters (prior to revising the document).

Trying the same tests with Alicao-2.txt should work correctly. When I encountered this problem in earlier versions of Sakai, it was not handling UTF-8 correctly. 2.1 seems to work correctly provided the file is UTF-8, so I think this bug is about as fixed as it can get.
column233:
One more thing to add about what is happening - in the specific case of files that are entered (not uploaded) as "simple text" and served as "text/plain" rather than "text/html", Sakai is suddenly switching to Latin-1 when serving the page. The file however is saved as UTF-8, and switching the encoding manually in the browser window will again reveal that the file is undamaged prior to revision.

Fixing this might be as simple as changing the default mime types to make sure text/plain documents get sent out as UTF-8, so it remains 100% consistent. Maybe.
column237: We need to deal with this, but there's nobody to work on it for 2.2. It seems like most of these problems are fixed by getting the right server settings, but some problems persist. We need a new analysis of what causes these problems.

column253:
The solution to this seems to be to track down any places where a new resource of type "text/*" is created and make sure to set the following property on it:

resourceProperties.addProperty(ResourceProperties.PROP_CONTENT_ENCODING, UTF_8_ENCODING);
column257:
Anybody watching this ticket have any suggestions? This was solved previously by a patch provided by David Roldan Martinez <darolmar@abierta.upv.es> and Raúl Enrique Mengod López <RMENGOD@upvnet.upv.es>. The key things that patch did was set the property mentioned above for new resources whose mimetype is text/plain or text/html. That was done as follows before saving new resources of those types:

resourceProperties.addProperty(ResourceProperties.PROP_CONTENT_ENCODING, UTF_8_ENCODING);

I'm pretty sure we're doing that now, but it doesn't seem to be working. Any suggestions would be appreciated.

column1: [SAK-1356] Tests and Quizzes (SAMigo) 2.0 patch 1
column6:
The attached .jar fixes some critical issues associated with the 2.0 release of Tests and Quizzes (SAMigo) tool. After installing Sakai, please follow these procedures to update your software:

**INSERT INSTRUCTIONS HERE**
column10: Tests and Quizzes (SAMigo) 2.0 patch 1
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/secure/attachment/10668/sakai2.sam-patch1.tar

The above patch addressed the critical bugs listed above.

Instruction for installing the patch over the sakai 2.0.0 source code

1. assume that you have download the source code for sakai2.0.0 at http://cvs.sakaiproject.org/release/2.0.0/sakai_2-0-0/sakai-src_2-0-0.zip
and have expanded it at your $HOME directory
> cd $HOME
> lynx http://cvs.sakaiproject.org/release/2.0.0/sakai_2-0-0/sakai-src_2-0-0.zip
> unzip sakai-src_2-0-0.zip

2. download the patch "sakai2.sam-patch1.tar" attached to this posting and expand it at $HOME
> cd $HOME
> lynx http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/secure/attachment/10668/sakai2.sam-patch1.tar
> tar xvf sakai2.sam-patch1.tar

3. assuming you have installed maven-1.0.2 and your maven's build.properties is set up
>more $HOME/build.properties

maven.repo.remote = http://www.ibiblio.org/maven/,http://cvs.sakaiproject.org/maven/
maven.tomcat.home = /usr/local/home/yourname/tomcat/

4. compile, create war files and deploy
> cd $HOME/sakai-src
> maven sakai
> /usr/local/home/yourname/tomcat/bin/startup.sh

5. If you have an existing MySQL instance that you installed for sakai 2.0.0,
please run the following script to update your existing tables
> mysql -u username -p schemaname < $HOME/sakai-src/sam/src/mysql/samigo-2.0.0.patch1.sql --force

Daisy
column90:

column1: [SAK-1353] Anonymous user's scoring
column6:
This has more to do with user documentation.

Once an anonmymous user (using a published assessment URL [PAU]) has submitted an assessment for grading, because there is no user id associated with the assessment, there is no way to go in and modify/review the grading.

Since the system does not automatically grade short answer/essay type question, and since there is no way to go in and regrade, I am hoping that somewhere there is user documentation that tell the creator of assessments that having questions of type 'short answer/essay' in assessments released to anonymous users does not make any sense.

ISSUE:
Verify that such documentation exists and has been made available.
column10: Anonymous user's scoring
column19: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
column55:
Hmmmm. Certainly you can modify and review the scores for an anonymously taken assessment. But if it's truly anonymous (someone took it via the URL, not when they were logged into Sakai) then you can't give them back the graded assessment afterward. They won't be able to see their final score or any comments you make. That's true for any question type, isn't it? Not just short answer ones.

The difference isn't so much whether the assessment is released to "anonymous" as whether someone takes it when they're logged into Sakai, or whether they take it from outside using the published assessment URL. You could certainly release an assessment to "anonymous", so it would show up in everybody's available list, and just not tell anyone about the direct URL. Then it wouldn't really be anonymous at all.

Yet another reason to change the names of the release to settings...Marc, feeling any more inclined toward the model I suggested a while back?
column90:
You're right. It has to do with how the assessment is taken. If an authenticated user takes the 'anonymously' distributed assessment, then a link is created, using either a name or id, and the submitted assessment can be access and re-graded if desired.

However, if the assessment is taken by someone who has not been authenticated, then NO link is created and there is no way for the grader to look at the answers that were provided.

I'm thinking here in terms of a survey, which is why I think the unauthenticated (ie. anonymous) user was allowed in the first place. For surveys, it is usually desirous to review the answers, and more often than not, there is usually a place for respondents to express themselves on some issue. However, with the current implementation, the personal expressions that take the form of input into short answer/essay (textbox) areas will not be viewable.
column95:
Hm, I'm not sure I'm following you. How come you can't view the text answers to anonymous assessments?

I just tried it again to make sure, on our latest qa instance (http://aam-dev.stanford.edu:18080/portal):

1) Logged in as marith/marith

2) Created assessment "6.21 anon delivery" in site Marith HSQLDB. Added a short answer and a survey question.

3) Published, releasing to anonymous users.

4) Logged out of sakai and took assessment via the direct URL:
http://aam-dev.stanford.edu:18080/samigo/servlet/Login?id=marith1119385289257

5) Submitted assessment for grading.

6) Logged back in as marith and viewed the assessment scores. There's my submission on the total scores page, with an ID of 1, and by clicking on it or by viewing the Question Scores page I can see my answer to the SA question.

Is this not working for you? I know it doesn't work on stable because of SAK-35744 Closed , but that's a bug and not an implementation decision.
column99:

(Look under the "Active" published assessments area.) Select the 'Scores' link and take a look at the entry. You will see that there is no link for you to view the actual questions.

This issues seems to me to be different from SAK-35744 Closed . Take a look and let me know what you think.
